Authors:
Serena Di Lenarda, Marta Martini, Stefano Borselli, Ruggero
Osler
Title:
Molecular and pathogenic characterization of strains of
Cadophora luteo-olivacea, the causal agent of kiwifruit skin pitting in
north-eastern Italy
Keywords:
Key words: Actinidia deliciosa, ITS, PCR-RFLP,
phylogenetic analysis, pathogenicity test
Abstract:
Skin pitting of kiwifruit is a post-harvest disease that
has been reported in Italy since the early 1990s; it first became
significant in Friuli Venezia Giulia (FVG, north-eastern Italy) in 2003.
Studies were carried out from 2005 to 2008 on symptomatic kiwifruit
(from four FVG orchards) using traditional and molecular techniques to
confirm the aetiology of the disease. The pathogen was isolated and
molecular identification was undertaken based on DNA extraction from the
mycelium, PCR (polimerase chain reaction) amplification with primers
ITS1/ITS4 and sequencing of the ITS (internal transcribed spacer)
region. Isolation assays showed a large presence of the fungus Cadophora
luteo-olivacea (= Phialophora luteo-olivacea) on the symptomatic areas.
Molecular characterization was conducted on 100 isolates and 6 CBS
(Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures) references strains of Cadophora
spp. by PCR (ITS1/ITS4)/RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphism)
analysis with HaeIII, BstUI and TaqI, permitting the identification of
different RFLP groups. The ITS portions of 28 isolates, chosen depending
on the RFLP group affiliation and orchard location, were sequenced and
BLAST analysis performed. Phylogenetic analysis based on the ITS
sequence was carried out including the sequences of some C.
luteo-olivacea strains obtained in recent studies and some CBS strains
of Cadophora spp. The molecular analyses mainly demonstrated the
presence of two different strains of C. luteo-olivacea, types -A and -B,
associated with skin pitting of kiwifruit. Pathogenicity tests using
spores of type -A and -B strains proved that both were able to produce
skin pitting.
